nexttext: ${U}_{l,k}$ and $\tilde{U}_{l,k}$ are the inverted value and synthetic truth for unknown variable $U$. The second norm at time step $l$ can be computed with:

where $M$ is the number of ensemble. 

All experimental and modeled results, no matter how carefully measured and calculated, contain some errors. In order to study the influence of errors on the final inversion results, we propose a simplified error model that includes observational and model errors. In terms of observational error, there are two major sources: systematic error, $\beta$, and measurement error. Here we assume that the measurement error is equal to the measurement greatest possible error, $\epsilon$. The measurement's greatest possible error is usually half of the smallest scale of the experiment equipment. The observational error for the sediment flux is a relative error:
prevtext: ${U}_{l,k}$ and $\tilde{U}_{l,k}$ are the inverted value and synthetic truth for unknown variable $U$. The second norm at time step $l$ can be computed with:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E2.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="{L_{2}^{l}}=\sqrt{\frac{\sum_{k=1}^{M}{\Big{(}\frac{U_{l,k}-\tilde{U}_{l,k}}{%
\tilde{U}_{l,k}}\Big{)}^{2}}}{M}}" display="block"><mrow><msubsup><mi>L</mi><mn>2</mn><mi>l</mi></msubsup><mo>=</mo><msqrt><mfrac><mrow><msubsup><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi>M</mi></msubsup><msup><mrow><mo maxsize="160%" minsize="160%">(</mo><mfrac><mrow><msub><mi>U</mi><mrow><mi>l</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>k</mi></mrow></msub><mo>-</mo><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>U</mi><mo stretchy="false">~</mo></mover><mrow><mi>l</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>k</mi></mrow></msub></mrow><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>U</mi><mo stretchy="false">~</mo></mover><mrow><mi>l</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>k</mi></mrow></msub></mfrac><mo maxsize="160%" minsize="160%">)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><mi>M</mi></mfrac></msqrt></mrow></math>

nexttext: in which $\tilde{m}_{l}$ is the true mass of the tsunami sediment for sample $l$ in given location. Also, the entire sediment is uniformly divided to several sediment samples to simplify the framework, therefore we also can write $E_{re}$ as:
prevtext:
where $M$ is the number of ensemble. 

All experimental and modeled results, no matter how carefully measured and calculated, contain some errors. In order to study the influence of errors on the final inversion results, we propose a simplified error model that includes observational and model errors. In terms of observational error, there are two major sources: systematic error, $\beta$, and measurement error. Here we assume that the measurement error is equal to the measurement greatest possible error, $\epsilon$. The measurement's greatest possible error is usually half of the smallest scale of the experiment equipment. The observational error for the sediment flux is a relative error:

in which $\tilde{m}_{l}$ is the true mass of the tsunami sediment for sample $l$ in given location. Also, the entire sediment is uniformly divided to several sediment samples to simplify the framework, therefore we also can write $E_{re}$ as:

in which $w_{i}$ is the settling velocity for grain size $i$, $z_0$ denotes the bed roughness and is calculated based on \citet{MacWilliams2005}. $z$ is elevation above sediment bed, and $k(z)$ represents the eddy viscosity profile from \citet{gelfenbaum1986}. 
In this equation, $C_{i, 0}$ denotes sediment concentration of the $i$\textsuperscript{th} grain-size class at the bed, which is calculated with \citet{Madsen19931303}:
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E5.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="C_{i}(z)=C_{i,0}e^{w_{i}\int_{z_{0}}^{z}{\frac{1}{K(z)}dz}}" display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>C</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>z</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><msub><mi>C</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>,</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><msub><mi>w</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="false"><msubsup><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><msub><mi>z</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mi>z</mi></msubsup></mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><mi>K</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>z</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><mi>z</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></msup></mrow></mrow></math>

where $\beta_{0}$ is the resuspension coefficient, $f_{i}$ is a fraction of the sediment of grain size $i$. $S_{i}$ is the normalized excess shear stress given by

prevtext:
where $\beta_{0}$ is the resuspension coefficient, $f_{i}$ is a fraction of the sediment of grain size $i$. $S_{i}$ is the normalized excess shear stress given by 

\begin{subequations}
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E7.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle S_{i}=\frac{\tau_{b}-\tau_{{cr}_{i}}}{\tau_{{cr}_{i}}}\>\>\>for%
\>\>\>\tau_{b}>\tau_{{cr}_{i}}" display="inline"><mrow><msub><mi>S</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mpadded width="+6.6pt"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mrow><msub><mi>τ</mi><mi>b</mi></msub><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>τ</mi><mrow><mi>c</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>r</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></mrow></msub></mrow><msub><mi>τ</mi><mrow><mi>c</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>r</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></mrow></msub></mfrac></mstyle></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mi>f</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>o</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+6.6pt"><mi>r</mi></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>τ</mi><mi>b</mi></msub></mrow><mo>></mo><msub><mi>τ</mi><mrow><mi>c</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>r</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></mrow></msub></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E8.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle S_{i}=0\>\>\>for\>\>\>\tau_{b}\leq\tau_{{cr}_{i}}" display="inline"><mrow><msub><mi>S</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mpadded width="+6.6pt"><mn>0</mn></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mi>f</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>o</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+6.6pt"><mi>r</mi></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>τ</mi><mi>b</mi></msub></mrow><mo>≤</mo><msub><mi>τ</mi><mrow><mi>c</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>r</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></mrow></msub></mrow></math>

nexttext: where $\kappa =0.41$ is the von Karman constant, $z$ is the elevation above bed, $h$ denotes the water depth and $u_*$ is the shear velocity. After determining the eddy viscosity profile, the flow speed profile is calculated by :

\end{subequations}
where $\tau_{b}$ is the bed shear stress and $\tau_{{cr}_{i}}$ is the critical shear stress of the initial sediment movement \citep{Madsen19931303}.  The eddy viscosity profile, $k(z)$,  from \citet{gelfenbaum1986} is given by:

nexttext: where $z_o$ is the bottom roughness from \citet{MacWilliams2005}. The total time taken for all the sediment in the water column to settle, $T$, is divided to $N$ time steps of size $\Delta t$ such that $T = N \, \Delta t$. For grain size class $i$, the water column can also be divided to $N$ layers. The sediment in layer $l$ consists of the sediment in the $l$\textsuperscript{th} layer of the water column for all grain size classes, which thickness $\Delta \eta_l$ is computed by:
prevtext: where $\kappa =0.41$ is the von Karman constant, $z$ is the elevation above bed, $h$ denotes the water depth and $u_*$ is the shear velocity. After determining the eddy viscosity profile, the flow speed profile is calculated by :
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E10.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\ U(z)=\int_{z_{0}}^{z}{\frac{u_{*}^{2}}{K(z)}dz}" display="block"><mrow><mrow><mpadded lspace="5pt" width="+5pt"><mi>U</mi></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>z</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><msubsup><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><msub><mi>z</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mi>z</mi></msubsup><mrow><mfrac><msubsup><mi>u</mi><mo>*</mo><mn>2</mn></msubsup><mrow><mi>K</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>z</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><mi>z</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext: in which $C_0$ is the total sediment concentration at the bed, $n$ is the number of grain size classes, and $\overline{C}_{i, l}$ is the average concentration of grainsize class $i$ in the water column layer $l$, which can be obtained by a simple integration:
prevtext: where $z_o$ is the bottom roughness from \citet{MacWilliams2005}. The total time taken for all the sediment in the water column to settle, $T$, is divided to $N$ time steps of size $\Delta t$ such that $T = N \, \Delta t$. For grain size class $i$, the water column can also be divided to $N$ layers. The sediment in layer $l$ consists of the sediment in the $l$\textsuperscript{th} layer of the water column for all grain size classes, which thickness $\Delta \eta_l$ is computed by:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E11.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\Delta\eta_{l}=\frac{1}{C_{0}}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n}{\overline{C}_{i,l}\,\Delta z%
_{i}}\right)," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>η</mi><mi>l</mi></msub></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mfrac><mn>1</mn><msub><mi>C</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi>n</mi></munderover><mrow><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>C</mi><mo>¯</mo></mover><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>l</mi></mrow></msub></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>z</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></mrow></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: The sediment flux is given by:
prevtext: in which $C_0$ is the total sediment concentration at the bed, $n$ is the number of grain size classes, and $\overline{C}_{i, l}$ is the average concentration of grainsize class $i$ in the water column layer $l$, which can be obtained by a simple integration:
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E12.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\bar{C}_{i,l}=\frac{1}{\Delta z_{i}}\int_{z}^{z+\Delta z_{i}}\,C_{i}(z)\,dz." display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>C</mi><mo stretchy="false">¯</mo></mover><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>l</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>z</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></mrow></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><msubsup><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mi>z</mi><mrow><mi>z</mi><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>z</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></mrow></mrow></msubsup></mpadded><mrow><msub><mi>C</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>z</mi><mo rspace="4.2pt" stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><mi>z</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext: The sediment flux is given by:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E13.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\zeta_{i,l}=\frac{\overline{C}_{i,l}\,\Delta z_{i}}{\Delta t}\quad\textrm{or
}\\
\zeta_{i,l}=\overline{C}_{i,l}\;w_{i}\quad\textrm{ in which }\quad w_{i}=\frac%
{\Delta z_{i}}{\Delta t}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>ζ</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>l</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>C</mi><mo>¯</mo></mover><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>l</mi></mrow></msub></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>z</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true"> </mo><mrow><mrow><mrow><mtext>or </mtext><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>ζ</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>l</mi></mrow></msub></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mpadded width="+2.8pt"><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>C</mi><mo>¯</mo></mover><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>l</mi></mrow></msub></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>w</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></mrow><mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true"> </mo><mtext> in which </mtext></mrow></mrow><mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true"> </mo><mrow><msub><mi>w</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>z</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
in which $\Delta T = \Delta N \Delta t$, indicating that the observation data is assimilated every
  $\Delta N$ time steps.

\item
  Estimate the
  mean $\bar{\mathbf{x}}$ and covariance $\mathbf{P}^{(n+1)}$ of the ensemble as:
  
  \begin{subequations}
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E15.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\hat{\mathbf{x}}_{j}^{(t+\Delta T)}=\mathcal{F}[\mathbf{x}_{j}^{(t)}]" display="block"><mrow><msubsup><mover accent="true"><mi>𝐱</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mi>j</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>T</mi></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msubsup><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">ℱ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msubsup><mi>𝐱</mi><mi>j</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msubsup><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

prevtext:
in which $\Delta T = \Delta N \Delta t$, indicating that the observation data is assimilated every
  $\Delta N$ time steps.

\item
  Estimate the
  mean $\bar{\mathbf{x}}$ and covariance $\mathbf{P}^{(n+1)}$ of the ensemble as:
  
  \begin{subequations}
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E16.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle\bar{\mathbf{x}}^{(t+\Delta T)}=\frac{1}{M}\sum_{j=1}^{N}{\hat{%
\mathbf{x}}^{(t+\Delta T)}_{j}}" display="inline"><mrow><msup><mover accent="true"><mi>𝐱</mi><mo stretchy="false">¯</mo></mover><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>T</mi></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msup><mo>=</mo><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mi>M</mi></mfrac></mstyle><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>j</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi>N</mi></munderover></mstyle><msubsup><mover accent="true"><mi>𝐱</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mi>j</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>T</mi></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msubsup></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E17.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle\mathbf{P}^{(t+\Delta T)}=\frac{1}{M-1}\sum_{j=1}^{N}{\left(\hat{%
\mathbf{x}}_{j}\hat{\mathbf{x}}_{j}^{\prime}-\bar{\mathbf{x}}\bar{\mathbf{x}}^%
{\prime}\right)^{(t+\Delta T)}}" display="inline"><mrow><msup><mi>𝐏</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>T</mi></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msup><mo>=</mo><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><mi>M</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mfrac></mstyle><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>j</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi>N</mi></munderover></mstyle><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mrow><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>𝐱</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mi>j</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mover accent="true"><mi>𝐱</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mi>j</mi><mo>′</mo></msubsup></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mover accent="true"><mi>𝐱</mi><mo stretchy="false">¯</mo></mover><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mover accent="true"><mi>𝐱</mi><mo stretchy="false">¯</mo></mover><mo>′</mo></msup></mrow></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>T</mi></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext: \item Update each sample in the predicted ensemble as follows:

prevtext: \item Update each sample in the predicted ensemble as follows:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E19.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\mathbf{x}_{j}^{(t+\Delta T)}=\hat{\mathbf{x}}_{j}^{(t+\Delta T)}+\mathbf{K}(%
\boldsymbol{\zeta}_{j}-\mathbf{H}\hat{\mathbf{x}}_{j}^{(t+\Delta T)})" display="block"><mrow><msubsup><mi>𝐱</mi><mi>j</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>T</mi></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msubsup><mo>=</mo><mrow><msubsup><mover accent="true"><mi>𝐱</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mi>j</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>T</mi></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msubsup><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi>𝐊</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msub><mi>𝜻</mi><mi>j</mi></msub><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>𝐇</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mover accent="true"><mi>𝐱</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mi>j</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>T</mi></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msubsup></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>
